command.intro: Builds individual fastq files for different samples from a single file containing reads from a whole sequencing lane (Former Deconvolute)
command.title: Demultiplexing reads
command.description: Builds individual fastq files for different samples from fastq files of complete sequencing lanes in which several samples were barcoded and sequenced. Several lane files can be provided with the option -d or a single file can be provided instead with the option -f (and -f2 for paired-end sequencing). If neither the -d or the -f options are specified, the program tries to read single sequencing reads from the standard input.
command.option: Tab-delimited file with at least four columns by default: flowcell, lane, barcode and sampleID. If the -a option for dual barcode is activated, five columns are expected: flowcell, lane, barcode1, barcode2 and sampleID. The file must have a header line. The same index file can be used to demultiplex several FASTQ files (see option -d).

Tab-delimited file listing the lane FASTQ files to be demultiplexed. Columns are: Flowcell, lane and fastq file (which can be gzip compressed). A second fastq file can be specified for pair-end sequencing. If the reads sequenced for one lane are split in multiple files, each file (or each pair of files) should be included in a separate row. If this option is used, the options -f, -f2, -c and -l are ignored.
Directory where the output fastq files will be saved. Files will be gzip compressed by default.
File with raw reads in fastq format. It can be gzip compressed.
File with raw reads in fastq format corresponding to the second file for paired end reads. It can be gzip compressed.
Id of the flowcell corresponding to the input fastq file(s). Ignored if the -d option is specified but required if -d option is not specified.
Id of the lane corresponding to the input fastq file(s). Ignored if the -d option is specified but required if the -d option is not specified.
Sequences to trim separated by comma. If any of the given sequences is found within a read, the read will be trimmed up to the start of the sequence.
Output uncompressed files.
Minimum read length to keep a read after trimming adapter sequences.
Activate demultiplexing with dual barcoding.

command.intro: Extract k-mers and count abundances from fasta and fastq files
command.title: Obtaining k-mers spectrum from sequences
command.description: Extracts k-mers and generates a distribution of k-mer abundances from a file of DNA sequences either in fastq or in fasta format (see -f option). Writes two files, one with the k-mer distribution and a second file with the actual k-mers and their counts.
command.option: Prefix of the output files.
K-mer length.
Minimum count to report a k-mer in the output file.
If set, only the forward strand would be used to extract kmers. Mandatory for non-DNA sequences.
Format of the input file(s). It can be 0 for fastq or 1 for fasta.
Ignore low complexity k-mers for counting and reporting.

command.intro: Corrects errors in read files based on k-mer abundance
command.title: Fixing sequencing errors
command.description: Builds a k-mer abundance profile and use this profile to identify and correct sequencing errors. For each predicted single nucleotide error, it looks for the single change that would create k-mers within the normal distribution of abundances. Using the option -e, this function can also receive a precalculated table of k-mers, which could come from a larger number of reads or reads sequenced using a different technology. For example, a k-mers profile based on Illumina reads could be built using the KmersExtractor command, and then this profile could be used to perform error correction on long reads.
command.option: Input file with raw reads in fastq or fasta format. See option -f for options on the file format. It can be gzip compressed.
Output file with the corrected reads in fastq format (gzip compressed).
Two column tab delimited file with k-mers and their abundances.
K-mer length.
Minimum k-mer count to consider a k-mer real.
If set, only the forward strand would be used to extract kmers. Mandatory for non-DNA sequences.
Format of the input file. It can be 0 for fastq or 1 for fasta.

command.intro: De novo variants discovery from a GBS experiment
command.title: Performing de-novo analysis of GBS reads
command.description: Performs de novo variants discovery from a genotype-by-sequencing (GBS) or a double digestion RAD sequencing (ddRAD) experiment. Runs a clustering algorithm based on quasi-exact matches to representative k-mers within the first base pairs of each sequence. Then, it performs variants detection and sample genotyping within each cluster using the same Bayesian model implemented for the reference-guided analysis. By now it can only discover and genotype Single Nucleotide Variants (SNVs).
command.option: Directory with fastq files to be analyzed. Unless the -d option is used, it processes as single reads all fastq files within the given directory.
Prefix for the output VCF file with the discovered variants and genotype calls as well as other output files describing the behavior of this process.

Tab delimited text file listing the FASTQ files to be processed for paired-end sequencing. It should have three columns. sample id, first fastq file and second fastq file. All files should be located within the directory provided with the option -i.
K-mer length.
Maximum number of read clusters to process. This parameter controls the amount of memory spent by the process.
Number of threads to process read clusters.
Maximum value allowed for a base quality score. Larger values will be equalized to this value.

Minimum variant quality. In this command, this filter applies to the QUAL column of the VCF, which is calculated for each variant as the maximum of the genotype qualities of samples with non-homozygous reference genotype calls. See the command VCFFilter to apply filters of quality and read depth on individual genotype calls.
Prior heterozygosity rate.
Default ploidy of the samples.

command.description: Builds a de-novo assembly from a set of long reads

command.title: Evaluating assembly graphs
command.description: Collects different statistics about assembly graphs generated by NGSEP. Also performs evaluation against a gold standard if the input reads are simulated or if they are aligned to a reference genome

command.intro: Builds a genome in fasta format from homozygous variants in a VCF file
command.title: Updating genomes from variants
command.description: Takes a VCF file with genotype information from one sample and the reference genome used to build the VCF and generates a new genome in fasta format modified using the alternative alleles from variants called as homozygous alternative within the individual. This can be useful to perform polishing of new genome assemblies using Illumina data, or in general to construct a haploid version of an individual genome
command.option: Fasta file with the original genome.
File in VCF format with the variants that will be applied to the input genome.
Output file in fasta format with the modified genome.

command.intro: Creates an FM index for indexing the genome
command.title: Indexing genome reference files
command.description: Creates a binary file containing an FM index for large sequences in fasta format (usually a reference genome). This structure facilitates performing massive text searches over the indexed sequence. This is a usual preparation step for alignment of short reads.
command.option: Input genome to index in fasta format. It can be gzip compressed.
Output binary file with the FM index associated with the input genome.

command.intro: Aligns sequencing reads to a reference genome
command.title: Aligning reads to reference genomes
command.description: Calculates a list of genomic regions for sites where the reads can be found in a reference genome. It receives up to two files with raw reads in fastq format and the reference genome. To map short reads to long genomes, a precalculated FM index can also be provided with the option -d. See command GenomeIndexer for construction of the FM index. It provides as output a file with alignments to the reference genome in BAM format.
command.option: Input file with raw reads in fastq format. It can be gzip compressed. Required if the second fastq file is provided using the option -i2.
Input file with raw reads in fastq format corresponding to the second file for paired end reads. It can be gzip compressed.

Text file with location of known short tandem repeats (STRs). It is a tab-delimited file with at least three columns: Sequence name (chromosome), region first base pair coordinate (1-based, inclusive) and region last base pair coordinate (1-based, inclusive).
Id of the sample.
Sequencing platform used to produce the reads. Supported platforms include ILLUMINA, IONTORRENT, PACBIO and ONT. Default: ILLUMINA

Maximum predicted insert length to consider an alignment proper.

command.intro: Detects sequencing error biases
command.title: Calculating base pair quality statistics
command.description: Takes one or more sets of alignments and a reference genome and counts the number of mismatches with the reference for each read position from 5' to 3' end. This report is useful to detect sequencing error biases. Requires one or more alignment files in SAM or BAM format, and the reference genome that was used to produce the alignments. Writes to standard output unless the -o option is used to specify an output file.
command.option: Output file with the base pair quality statistics.
Fasta file with the reference genome.
Minimum mapping quality to call an alignment unique.

command.intro: Shows the uniformity of the sequencing process over the genome
command.title: Calculating coverage statistics
command.description: Calculates the number of base pairs that are covered by reads at each read depth level from 1 to a maximum. Alignments must be in SAM or BAM format. Writes to standard output unless the -o option is used to specify an output file.
command.option: Input file with alignments to analyze.
Output file with the coverage distribution.
Minimum mapping quality to call an alignment unique.

command.intro: Module for direct calculation of variants from multiple samples.
command.title: Calling variants over multiple samples
command.description: This module allows to call variants over a group of samples separated by files or read group tags. This is now the recommended method to perform variants detection on genotype-by-sequencing (GBS), RAD sequencing, whole exome sequencing (WES), RNA-seq and low coverage (less than 10x) whole genome sequencing (WGS) data. Although it can also be used on high coverage WGS data, the classic sample-by-sample analysis (commands FindVariants, MergeVariants and MergeVCF) is still recommended to identify structural variants. This module requires one or more read alignment files in SAM or BAM format and the reference genome that was used to produce the alignments.
command.option: Fasta file with the reference genome.
Output VCF file with discovered variants and genotype calls.
Default ploidy of the samples.

In this command, this filter applies to the QUAL column of the VCF, which is calculated for each variant as the maximum of the genotype qualities of samples with non-homozygous reference genotype calls. See the command FilterVCF to apply filters of quality and read depth on individual genotype calls.
Flag to call SNVs within STRs. By default, STRs are treated as a single locus and hence no SNV will be called within an STR.

command.intro: Performs single individual molecular haplotyping

command.intro: Calculates the distribution of relative allele counts
command.title: Obtaining relative allele counts from read alignment files
command.description: Calculates a distribution of relative allele counts for sites showing base calls for more than one nucleotide from read alignment files in BAM format. This analysis is useful to predict the ploidy of a sequenced sample.

command.intro: Compares the read depth of two samples
command.title: Comparing read depth between samples
command.description: This function compares the read depth of two samples to predict regions with relative copy number variation (CNV) between a sample and a control. It takes two alignment files and a reference genome, splits the genome into windows, and for each window compares the read depth between the two samples. It outputs a text file containing the list of windows of the genome in which the normalized read depth ratio between the two samples is significantly different from 1 (See README.txt for details).
command.option: Input sorted BAM file with alignments to a reference genome.
Sorted BAM file corresponding to the control (wild type) sample.
File with genomic regions in which the two samples have different read depth.
Fasta file with the reference genome.
Window length to be used during the read depth comparison.

command.intro: Provides statistics on a transcriptome file in GFF3 format

command.intro: Generates a VCF file which includes the functional information related with each variant.

command.intro: Implements different filters on VCF files with genotype information
command.title: Filtering VCF files

First, it executes the distance filter (-d), then the filtering of samples and genotypes (-saf, -fs, -q and -minRD). Finally, it recalculates the number of samples genotyped, the number of alleles called and the MAF to execute the remaining filters. Reads from standard input unless the -i option is used. Writes to standard output unless the -o option is used. Since version 2.0.6, the default behavior does not perform any filtering.

command.intro: Calculates a genetic distance matrix from genomic variants in a given VCF file
command.title: Calculation of genetic distance matrices from VCF files
command.description: Generates a distance matrix from a variants file in VCF format. The matrix is calculated using the basic IBS (Identity by state) algorithm. However, four options to infer the genotype call information are implemented. In particular, users can choose predicted allele dosages of CNVs or direct estimations of allele dosage per site per individual based on relative allele-specific read counts. The latter option is useful to improve distance estimations in polyploids. It writes the matrix of genetic distances in a generic format. Reads from standard input unless the -i option is used to specify an input file. Writes to standard output unless the -o option is used to specify an output file.
command.option: Input file in VCF format. It can be gzip compressed.
Output file with the distance matrix. See -f for options on the output format.

Source of information in the VCF file to calculate distances. 0 for simple genotype calls (GT format field), 1 for allele copy number (ACN format field), 2 for total copy number (total of ACN format field), and 3 for raw allele depth (ADP or BSDP format fields).
Matrix output format, 0 is full matrix, 1 lower-left matrix and 2 is upper right matrix.
Default ploidy of the samples. Used if the distance source (-s option) is the raw allele depths to recalculate allele dosage based on these counts.

command.intro: Construct a neighbor joining dendrogam given a distance matrix file
command.title: Building dendrogams using the Neighbor-Joining algorithm
command.description: Given a distance matrix file, this command builds a dendogram for graphical display of genetic distances using the Neighbor Joining algorithm. The distance matrix can be provided as an upper, lower or full matrix. The dendrogam is written in Newick format. Reads from standard input unless the -i option is used to specify an input file. Writes to standard output unless the -o option is used to specify an output file.
command.option: Input file with a distance matrix.
Output file with the dendrogam in Newick format.

command.intro: Calculates allele sharing diversity statistics, either through windows or through genes for inbred populations
command.title: Calculating allele sharing statistics
command.description: Calculates allele sharing diversity statistics, either through windows across the genome or through the genes catalog of the species. This program calculates the pairwise differences between every pair of samples in the VCF file and uses that information to calculate diversity statistics such as the average number of pairwise differences per Kbp, Fst and Tajima D. This functionality should only be applied to VCFs containing populations of inbred samples. Each group can either be one or more than populations within the populations file. Multiple population names within one group should be separated by comma (without white spaces). The populations file is a tab-delimited text file with two columns: sample id and population id. Reads from standard input unless the -i option is used to specify an input file. Writes to standard output unless the -o option is used to specify an output file. See the README.txt file for details on the output.
command.option: Input file in VCF format. It can be gzip compressed.
File with population assignments for the samples. A two column text file with the sample ids in the first column and the ids of the populations in the second column.
Output file with statistics.
Comma-separated list of populations that should be considered as group 1.
Comma-separated list of populations that should be considered as group 2.
GFF3 file with the transcriptome. If this file is provided, statistics will be provided by gene and not by window.
If set, introns will be included in the calculation of pairwise differences. Only useful if the -t option is set.
Length of each genomic window to calculate pairwise differences between samples.
Step between windows to calculate pairwise differences between samples.

command.intro: Imputes missing genotypes from unphased multilocus SNP genotype data in a VCF.
command.title: Genotype imputation
command.description: This module allows imputation of missing genotypes from unphased multilocus SNP genotype data in a VCF. The current version is a reimplementation of the Hidden Markov Model (HMM) implemented in the package fastPHASE This implementation allows to process VCF files and produces its output also as a VCF. However, only biallelic SNPs are imputed and included in the output VCF file. The current version supports imputation of either highly homozygous or heterozygous populations. Parental lines can be provided for both types of populations using the -p option. The options -ip and -is tell the model that either the parental accessions (-ip) or the entire population (-is) are inbred samples with low heterozygosity. In the latter mode, the model will only produce homozygous genotype calls. See the README.txt file for details on the output files.
command.option: Input file in VCF format. It can be gzip compressed.
Prefix of the output files.
Comma-separated list of sample ids of the parents of the population. Only to be used for bi-parental or multi-parental breeding populations.

Maximum number of groups in which local haplotypes will be clustered. For bi-parental or multi-parental breeding populations please set explicitly the number of parents of the population even if the list of parents is provided with the -p option. This allows to take into account cases of populations in which some of the parents are missing
Window size as number of variants within each window.
Overlap as number of variants shared between neighbor windows.
Estimated average number of centiMorgans per Kbp on euchromatic regions of the genome. Typical values of this parameter are 0.001 for human populations, 0.004 for rice and 0.35 for yeast populations.

If set, transition probabilities in the HMM will NOT be updated during the Baum-Welch training of the HMM. Not recommended unless the -c option is set to a value allowing a reasonable initial estimation of the transition probabilities.
Specifies that parents of the population are inbred.
Specifies that the samples to impute are inbred.

command.intro: Runs a window-based haplotype introgression analysis.
command.title: Finding haplotype introgressions
command.description: Runs a window-based analysis to identify the most common haplotype within each of the populations described in the given populations file and then identify common haplotypes of one population introgressed in samples of a different population. Although it can be run on any VCF file, it is particularly designed to work with populations of inbred samples. Reads from standard input unless the -i option is used to specify an input file. See the README.txt file for details on the output files.
command.option: Input file in VCF format. It can be gzip compressed.
File with population assignments for the samples. A two column text file with the sample ids in the first column and the ids of the populations in the second column.
Prefix of the output files.
Minimum percentage of samples genotyped within a population to identify the most common allele.
Minimum difference between reference allele frequencies of at least two populations to consider a variant discriminative.
Maximum minor allele frequency within a population to consider the major allele of a variant as representative allele for such population.
Window size as number of variants within each window.
Overlap as number of variants shared between neighbor windows.
Score given of a match between a sample homozygous genotype call and a population major allele.
Score given of a mismatch between a sample homozygous genotype call and a population major allele.
Minimum score to match a sample haplotype with a population-derived haplotype.
Outputs a VCF file with the biallelic variants that showed segregation between at least one pair of groups and hence were selected for the analysis.
If set, reports introgression events for unassigned haplotypes according to the minimum score defined by the options -a -t and -s.

command.intro: Simulates a single individual with homozygous and heterozygous mutations from a reference genome
command.title: Simulating individuals from a reference genome
command.description: This simulator takes a (haploid) genome assembly and simulates a single individual including homozygous and heterozygous mutations (SNPs, indels and mutated STRs) relative to the input assembly. It produces two files, a fasta file with the simulated genome, and a phased VCF file with the simulated variants.
